The following is a mixed bag of issues, thoughts and suggestions that
occur=
red to me during the last few weeks as I worked on the AR module and
was ma=
naging a broad crawl. Some are more thought out then others and their
impor=
tance varies wildly. 

Some of this is posted here to get some discussion, =
other bits are mostly
pointed at the boys at the Archive. Basically, this i=
s a mixed bag.

Remaining time

This feature is of negligible use and is mo=
re likely to confuse than inform
users. The time estimate is only going to =
give a reasonable figure if there
is only one host left (or several hosts w=
ith a similar number of documents)
and we're already done with the 'discove=
ry' phase. This may be of use
towards the end of some focused crawls, but g=
enerally this is of little
value. Since this value is almost always wrong I=
 believe that it is far more
likely to confuse users. I also find it annoyi=
ng to have another time
counter as I occasionally get it mixed up when I'm =
looking up the duration
of the crawl, but that's a lesser issue.

Unless th=
e estimate can be improved significantly (and this requires taking
into acc=
ount the number of queues and their relative sizes and the
politeness restr=
ictions for anything approaching a reasonable estimate) I
vote to remove th=
is feature.


The 'Crawl resuming' at the top of the progress-statistics.lo=
g

A change to how the crawls are started has led to a CRAWL RESUMING being=

printed at the top of the progress-statistics.log. Perhaps the events need=

to be augmented to include a CRAWL STARTING that the progress-statistics.l=
og
would ignore. In any case, this needs to be fixed.


Include actual memo=
ry used in the progress-statistics.log instead of or in
addition to current=
 heap size.

Actual memory used is of much greater interest, especially whe=
n looking
through the log to see memory usage trends.


Default Bdb cache p=
ercent to something modest, like 35-40% (OOM errors)

The AR module encount=
ered some issues with the default setting. I'm not
going to vote for any on=
e value, but I suggest that crawls should always
retain a good chunk of mem=
ory after the Bdb cache grows to its maximum
allowed size.


Get rid of the=
 recovery journal in favor of decent crash resistance via Bdb 

This is a b=
igger issue (and I know it's something you guys want to do). The
recovery j=
ournal has never (for me) worked as a crash recovery tool. The AR
frontier =
is able to reconstruct itself based on its databases without any
trouble. I=
f done right, resuming a crawl could be done in a matter of
seconds, instea=
d of hours (or days). I'd vote to make this the #1 priority
for 1.6!


Allo=
w frontiers to provide 'servlets' that enables more detailed monitoring
and=
 control.

I don't really care how it's done, but we need to allow modules,=
 especially
(or even exclusively) Frontiers, need to have customized contro=
l pages!


Display data, 4GB should be 4.442GB etc.

Need to improve how da=
ta amounts are condensed, currently the jump from
4095MB to 4GB lacks granu=
larity. I'd be happy to fix this if we could agree
on exactly how things ar=
e supposed to be. My suggestion: show four
characters. So we'd go from 4095=
 MB to 4GB and then 4.001GB etc. when we hit
40GB we go to 40.01 etc. same =
for the move from B to KB and KB to MB

Additionally, we could have a mouse=
-over pop up the exact number of bytes.


Default log lines to show be 40 i=
nstead of 50

A bit of a nit-pick. I've got a screen running at 1024 lines =
of vertical
resolution and 40 lines fill up my screen. Since not many users=
 are likely
to have higher resolution (in fact I'd expect the average to be=
 lower) I
suggest we amend the default value to 40 (or possibly 35).


Link=
 from help to /help/regexpr.jsp

I find this page invaluable when adding ne=
w regular expressions, especially
to crawls in progress. Lets you double ch=
eck those reg.expr. using the same
interpreter. The page has been available=
 for awhile, but either the link was
dropped or it never existed. Either wa=
y, a link should be added to the help
page.


Cost assignment on -5000/-500=
1

More of a question, do URIs that return with -500X 'cost' anything? I'd
=
suggest that they shouldn't. After all, they aren't actually crawled. 


Ho=
stnameQueueAssignmentPolicy attaches the port number to the hostname

Is th=
is really sensible considering that these are used as the basic
politeness =
units. Different ports, same server. I'd think we'd want to
handle it all t=
he same way.


Daily reports? Detailed look at the crawl, printed to a file=
 daily? 

I was thinking that it might be nice to add a 'Daily report' feat=
ure to the
StatisticsTracker. It would generate a (new) report file at a sp=
ecified time
each day. Information regarding the number of URIs, amount of =
data,
bandwidth usage etc. would be printed, giving a nice summary on the p=
rogress
so far.


URI reg.expr filter (OR based) that has a list of strings=
 instead of just
one.

I find myself using a series of URI reg.expr. filter=
s to tackle numerous
issues. I was thinking that it might be useful to add =
a similar filter that
contained a list of strings. This would make it a lot=
 easier to add
additional filters while a crawl is in progress. I can handl=
e this if you
agree it's a good idea.


In help (and perhaps a link from th=
e logs) provide a quick link to the
result codes (local, not on web).

I fi=
nd myself looking these up a lot. Having a handy, local reference would
be =
useful. Should include both the HTTP codes and the ones specified by
Heritr=
ix.


Changes to Meta-data, description do not have any effect.

This has b=
een around for awhile I think. The only time this is written is
when a prof=
ile/job is created. Changes seem to have no effect.


Add items crawled to =
Bdb reports for each queue.

The BdbFrontier report should list the number =
or URIs crawled for each
queue. Currently you can sort of calculate this ba=
sed on the expenditure and
average cost (which is of little use of you are =
using
ZeroCostAssignmentPolicy).


BdbFrontier: Add a log that details when=
 queues are created and move from
active to inactive and finally to exhaust=
ed.

This would make it easier to monitor crawls. Basically when a queue mo=
ves
between any of the above states a line should be written in the log. Th=
is
way you could quickly grep through the log and see how that queue is bei=
ng
processed. 

The log line might look something like this:

[time-date] [=
queue-name] [old state] [new state] [queue-size] [URIs crawled]
[total expe=
nded] [last cost] [average cost]


- Kris
